thread.title: Washington and Sunderland West constituency General Election 2017 - candidates and history of seat

author: Mike Kelly
title: Washington and Sunderland West constituency General Election 2017 - candidates and history of seat
text:
Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now Get daily updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Thank you for subscribing! Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email 
If you’re due to cast your vote in the Washington and Sunderland West constituency on June 8 we’ve got everything you need to know right here. 
Britain will go to the polls to elect a Government and Prime Minister after Theresa May called a snap General Election . 
We’ll be covering events on our live blog on election day, but in the meantime we’ve got the information you need before you decide which box to put your cross in. 
Which parties and candidates standing in Washington and Sunderland West ? Labour - Sharon Hodgson Sharon Hodgson (Photo: ©Flying Colours Photography Ltd) 
Sharon grew up on Tyneside and taught in several local schools in the region. 
Before becoming a politician, she was an administrator and book keeper for Northern Rock before she took the role of Administrator for the “Total Learning Challenge”, a North East charity providing early intervention for children at risk of dropping out of education and their communities. 
As a governor of her children’s school in Dunston , treasurer of a Gateshead playgroup and Women’s Officer for Tyne Bridge Labour party, Mrs Hodgson was an active party member and campaigner for many years. Green - Michal Chantkowski 
Michal has lived in Wearside for a number of years. He was born in Poland which he says gives him a fresh perspective and helps him develop ideas. 
A keen local community volunteer enabling understanding between different ethnic communities and standing up for people’s rights, with regards to access to welfare or housing, or rights at work. Conservative - Jonathan Gullis 
Jonathan qualified as a teacher in 2012 and worked in a London school for three years before moving back to work in Warwickshire as of June 2015. He is also a trade union representative and part of the Club Management Team at Stratford Town FC. 
He says his experience in working with young people is what has driven him to support what he sees as Theresa May’s vision of building a society that works for everyone. Lib Dem - Tom Appleby 
Tom was born in Hexham and has lived in the North East nearly all of his life. 
He went to state schools at Wylam First, Ovingham Middle, Prudhoe High and then went to Northumbria University where he gained degrees in politics and law. 
Tom currently works in an insurance firm in Newcastle, having previously worked as a paralegal for several local law firms. UKIP - Bryan Foster 
Bryan was born in Plains Farm, Sunderland and has lived the majority of his life in and around the city, and is now living in Ryhope. 
He attended Springwell Infant School and Havelock Junior School and Bede Grammar School before getting married and being a father to two children. 
On leaving Bede Grammar School, Bryan started a career in retailing then he worked alongside his wife for several years in her business and became a founder member of Sunderland City Centre Traders Association. 
Bryan joined UKIP in April 2013 and is an active member within the party. He was the Social Secretary in 2014 and in 2017 became Chairman of Sunderland & Washington branch. 
He stood as candidate for Sunderland Central in the 2015 general election. What was the result in Washington and Sunderland West in 2015? 
Sharon Hodgson (Lab): 20,478 (55.0%) 
Aileen Casey (UKIP) 7,321 (19.6%) 
Bob Dhillon (Con): 7,033 (18.9%) 
Anthony Murphy (Green): 1,091 (2.9%) 
Dominic Haney (Lib Dem) 993 (2.7%) 
Gary Duncan (TUSC): 341 (0.9%) 
Turnout: 54.6% 
Winner: Sharon Hodgson (majority, 13,157). Read More General Election: How the North East voted last time - and where June's battles will be fiercest Which parties and MPs have held the seat in the past? 
Another safe Labour seat although the area’s fervent backing of Brexit could sow the seeds for division among its traditional support. 
However it would require a virtually unheard of 17.7% swing for Labour to lose a seat held by Sharon Hodgson since it was created in 2010. 
The town of Washington has a well-preserved historic centre with a museum dedicated to the first United States president, on its outskirts, the family home of George Washington. 
The constituency is composed of elements of the following predecessors: Houghton and Washington East; Gateshead East and Washington West; Sunderland North; and Sunderland South.
